Understates: The claim that "We got back every dime used to rescue the banks" is an understatement because it implies that the full amount of money used to rescue the banks has been returned, when in reality, only a portion has been returned.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support because it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the statement that every dime used to rescue the banks has been returned.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the amount returned from the bank bailouts is equivalent to the amount initially invested, without considering other factors such as interest and dividends.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, which is that while a significant amount of money has been returned from the bank bailouts, it does not necessarily mean that every dime has been recovered in full.
